title: Lab 4 — Incident Response: Evidence Preservation Challenge

report.summary: User reports multiple unexpected MFA prompts. The user says they did not initiate any sign-in attempts and is concerned someone is trying to access the account.

instructor_guidance: This lab is about ordering: preserve evidence before containment changes state.
Encourage teams to write a one-sentence justification before each action.
Most teams will want to reset passwords immediately—pause and ask what evidence that might remove or complicate.
A strong first-three sequence usually includes: preserve identity logs, collect user statement, and snapshot active sessions/device info before revoking everything.
Debrief: what evidence was lost, and how would that change your confidence about what happened?

evidence.title: Recent Sign-in History
evidence.description: A synthetic list of recent sign-ins (timestamps, device label, success/failure, MFA result). Useful for building the timeline.

evidence.title: MFA Prompt Events
evidence.description: A synthetic record of MFA prompts sent, approved/denied, and method type (push vs number match).

evidence.title: Active Sessions Snapshot
evidence.description: A point-in-time snapshot showing active sessions and sign-in tokens currently valid.

evidence.title: User Statement
evidence.description: What the user saw, when they saw it, what they clicked, and whether they approved any prompts.

evidence.title: Admin Audit Log
evidence.description: A synthetic audit log of recent account changes (password reset, MFA changes, group membership, forwarding rules).

evidence.title: Mailbox Rules Snapshot
evidence.description: A snapshot of forwarding rules and inbox rules that may indicate compromise persistence.

actions.title: Export sign-in history and MFA event logs
actions.description: Preserve identity logs for the last 72 hours (sign-ins, MFA challenges, failures/successes).

actions.title: Interview user and document what happened
actions.description: Ask whether any prompts were approved, when prompts started, and what devices were in use.

actions.title: Snapshot active sessions before changing credentials
actions.description: Record active sessions/tokens, device list, and recent session creation times.
risks: Low risk; helps confirm ongoing access

actions.title: Review admin audit log for account changes
actions.description: Look for password changes, MFA method changes, mailbox forwarding rules, or privilege changes.

actions.title: Capture mailbox forwarding and inbox rules
actions.description: Snapshot mailbox rules to check for persistence (forwarding, auto-delete, move rules).
risks: Low risk; high value for account compromise cases

actions.title: Force password reset immediately
actions.description: Reset password and require re-authentication across devices.
risks: High: can invalidate sessions before you capture them

actions.title: Revoke all active sessions and tokens
actions.description: Revoke sessions/tokens to immediately stop any ongoing attacker access.
risks: High: can destroy session artifacts if not captured first

actions.title: Disable account temporarily
actions.description: Disable the account to stop access while the team investigates.
risks: High: stops access but can remove live-session context if not captured first
